Hello All !

I'm Umer, from Pakistan. I completed my BS in Computer Systems 
Engineering from GIK Institute, Pakistan this May. During my last two 
semesters, I worked on "Developing Collective Intelligent Behavior" 
as my Senior Design Project. The technique we (me and 3 other guyz) 
used, was NEAT. We worked in Visual C++, with OpenGL for our 
Simulation displays. 

We made environments with obstacles and lights and many robots (going 
from 2 to hundreds). The robots had simple IR transmitters and 
receivers, bump sensors, light detectors. 

We tried to evolve simple behaviors like, gathering, flocking, 
following the leader, finding light, predator-prey. In gathering, 
flocking, and finding light all the robots had the same neural nets 
to make decisions (Inputs from IR sensors, light, bump senors.. 
outputs to motors, and IR transmitter). Whereas, in the case of 
following the leader and predator-prey, we had two classes of neural 
nets. 

As you might have guessed, working with hundreds of robots for many 
generations is computationally very expensive. So, we made a 
distributed version of NEAT. The simulations were carried out on 
different client machines (mostly pIIs and pIIIs in our AI Lab), 
while there was one master server that carried out "epoch"s of NEAT 
and gave new chromosomes to every new coming client. 

Some of the results we came up with were very interesting. Especially 
in flocking, we could see robots behave like birds. they formed small 
groups, sometimes even spirals (with slower robots on the inner side 
of the spiral and faster ones towards the outer edges). We evolved 
some neural nets with 3-4 robots, and tried the same net for 50-60 
robots and found that the neural nets didn't work all that bad for 
greater number of robots.

In the "finding light" behavior, the robots usually tended to follow 
the walls of the room in which they were kept to come to the light 
(which was normally placed at a corner). But when we placed the 
lights somewhere in the middle of the room, then due to the physical 
limitations of the robot, it could not find out where the lights 
were. But once it got in the range of the light, it managed to sit 
under it. 

The results of following the leader and predator-prey were not 
satisfactory. The predators tended to catch each other, the followers 
tended to get stuck with each other. But, I think that was due to the 
limitations of the robots. Since, they could not distinguish between 
predator, prey etc.

I will write more about my work later. 

Although, now I dont get anytime to work on NEAT. Since, I'm working 
with a software house these days, and am preparing for my GRE. I hope 
to get into a Phd program where I can continue my work with NEAT. 

If anyone of you is interested in my work, feel free to ask :)

I will probably be just a reader of this group unless I get time to 
restart my work. :)

Regards,
- Umer
